Compressed air energy storage is a promising technology which may allow us to store energy gathered from renewable sources for later use.
However, it's not a perfect storage solution; compressing air generates heat which might be lost, and expanding compressed air to reclaim energy requires heat to reach max efficiency.
If the heat from compression can be stored for use during expansion, the efficiency of the system can increase dramatically.
Use the air compressors to either side to explore one way that researchers are trying to store heat for later use.

Compress air in the Right Compressor…
and hold
for 1, 2, 3. Watch the Graph.
Notice this:
The Right Graph doesn’t rise as
high as the Left one did but it doesn’t fall as
far either. Not as much heat and pressure is
lost.
What’s happening?
Find the heat sink—a
rolled up screen in the right compressor. The screen absorbs some
of the heat you generate, which is then stored in the water.
Since air in the right compressor didn’t heat up as much,
you didn’t work as hard to
compress it.

Notice this:
The area between the two
curves curves—the record of your
work—on the Right Graph is smaller than
this area on the Left Graph.
What’s happening?
The heat-trapping screen
nested in the Right Compressor recycles the
heat you generate, resulting in less wasted
work.
So what?
This experiment shows promise
for heat-recycling research underway at the
University of Minnesota’s Center for
Compact and Efficient Fluid Power.
